payload.h1: Welcome to the iSCAPE Citizen Kit!
payload.h4: Let’s get you set up with a Smart Citizen Kit, and sensing in no time!

payload.h2: Smart Citizen is a movement for civic participation in a modern world
payload.h4: Smart Citizen creates open tools for citizens to be better informed about the world around them.

payload.h2: The Smart Citizen Kit
payload.h4: This sensor is a Smart Citizen Kit for environmental sensing. It measures sound, air quality, humidity, and lots of other things

payload.h2: smartcitizen.me
payload.h4: The kit sends all the measurements to the Smart Citizen website. It's open and free for all to see, question and play with...
There's a few pieces we need to set up the Kit, let's check we have them all

payload.h2: Click on all the things you have received
payload.h4: We need to know this to make the set up work smoothly
payload.part1_desc: This is where all the sensors are. It connects to the bigger, hardware board, so that the sensors can transmit what they find.
payload.part2_desc: This is where all the computation takes place. Anytime you want to connect something to the Smart Citizen, it will be on this board
payload.part3_desc: This powers the device. Every so often it has to be recharged, especially after long periods of continuous use.
payload.part4_desc: When the Kit needs to be charged, you can connect this cable to your computer or plug, and back to the Kit.

payload.h2: Finally...
payload.h4: You don’t have to have the case, but it does protect your kit against the elements
payload.part5_desc: The case is water resistant and allows the device to be affixed to a variety of surfaces.
payload.part6_desc: Placed between the hardware board and sensor board, this keeps the boards study.
payload.part7_desc: Closing the case, this is used dto protect the device from rain. Make sure to place the holes over the sound sensor.
payload.part8_desc: This is used to fasten the case to the cover.

payload.h4: Now let's put it all together

payload.h2: First the separators...
payload.text: Place a spacer in the holes on the sensor board

payload.h2: Secondly, let's connect the sensors
payload.text: Connect the pins on the sensor board to the hardware board

payload.h2: Let's give it some power
payload.text: Connect the battery to the hardware board

payload.h2: And finally, turn on the Kit
payload.text: Push the button on the Kit multiple times, until the LED is red.

payload.h2: Next, we'll place it all in the casing
payload.text: Make sure you place it with the battery cable towards the bottom of the casing

payload.h2: ... and to finish, seal the cover
payload.text: Place the transparent plastic on the front of the case and fix it in place with the two white plugs.

payload.h2: What network are we connecting it to?
payload.h4: We have to type it in manually...
payload.input1_error: A name is required to connect to a network

payload.h2: Now let's do some magic..
payload.h4: Hold up your kit and press it on the screen over the box below and press 'connect'. Make sure the blue side of the kit is facing you

payload.h2: Oops, something went wrong...
payload.h4: It seems there is a problem. Notice that the Kit light is red, please retry the Wi-Fi name and password
payload.input1_error: A name is required to connect to a network

payload.h4: You've connected the kit to the internet!

payload.h4: This approach is more reliable. You will need a phone or tablet.

payload.h1: LET'S GIVE YOUR SENSOR AN IDENTITY
payload.h4: This will help us know where this data is coming from...

payload.h2: What shall we name the sensor?
payload.h4: You can name it pretty much anything. This is how it will appear on the Smart Citizen map.

payload.h2: Where will you install the sensor?
payload.h4: By pressing 'allow' on the pop up we can determine the current location of the sensor. You can manually adjust this later to anywhere you want to place the sensor.

payload.h2: If you want to adjust it or pin it elsewhere, you can do that here
payload.h4: Remember wherever your device goes, it will need wi-fi. Otherwise you'll have to go get it every now and again and connect it to your computer to sync the data

payload.h2: Is there anything we should know about location?
payload.h4: Selecting from the tags below can help us make sense of the data, and compare it more accurately
Finally, let's save all this work we've done.

payload.h2: We can save the Kit with your email address
payload.h4: If you already have an account, we'll add it to that. If not, we'll quickly make a new one

payload.h2b: enter your password below to finish!
payload.h4: This will push all of your new Kit's data to your account

payload.h2: Nice, so you're new to Smart Citizen?
payload.h4: Add a username to your profile, so users know who owns the sensor.

payload.h2: Now, filly a password to secure everything
payload.h4a: the password has to be at least 8 characters long
payload.h4b: And one more time to make sure there are no mistakes
payload.input1_error: The password must be at least 8 characters long

payload.h2: You have successfully installed and connected the Smart Citizen Kit to the internet, and then added the kit to the global community of sensors
payload.h4: Visit SmartCitizen.me to see your Kit in action capturing data. Don't forget to read the manual for assembly instructions and good tips on placing your sensor in the wild
